newsitem.title: USA: Transitional to discuss merger with Vencor.
newsitem.headline: Transitional to discuss merger with Vencor.

text.p: Transitional Hospitals Corp., after agreeing to a buyout by Select Medical Corp., said Friday it would begin merger talks with Vencor Inc. which is offering a higher bid of $639 million in cash.

Vencor, a diversified provider of health care services, offered $16 a share on Wednesday, days after Transitional said it had a definitive agreement to be acquired by Select for $14.55 a share, or $564.5 million.
Transitional said the deal with Select, based in Mechanicsburg, Pa., allows it to enter into discussions with unsolicited bidders.
Transitional Chairman Richard Conte said the action was consistent with the Las Vegas-based company's commitment to maximizing shareholder value.
Analysts have said that Vencor is likely to emerge as winner in the bidding war because it has the deepest pockets.

The combination of Vencor and Transitional, which operates long-term acute care hospitals, would advance the growth strategy of Vencor, the nation's largest full-service long-term health care provider.

The combined company would have 57 hospitals, 314 skilled nursing centres, 4,000 institutional customers for contract rehabilitation services, 80,000 employees and pro forma annual revenues of $3.3 billion. Vencor, based in Louisville, Ky., said it would retain all of Transitional's non-administrative employees, but did not say how many people might be laid off.

The Vencor offer is scheduled to expire June 4, and is subject to the tender of at least two-thirds of Transitional's fully diluted common shares and equivalents. The offer has no financing contingency.
Vencor's stock rose 12.5 cents to $37.75, while Transitional was unchanged at $15.50 on the New York Stock Exchange at midday.
